content.description: 5th class gully splitting the entire formation goes on 200 feet or so of sandstone.  Stemming up the walls and smooth foot and hand placement will advance you onto chockstone stances to the top.  This route is usually done without any gear or ropes due to the low difficulty.  A fall, however unlikely, could be dangerous.
content.location: From Sentinel Rock follow hiking trails down to the base of the formation.  Once at the bottom of the formation start up the most obvious Northwest facing 5th class gully that splits the formation.

content.description: Start on southern face of Sentinel rock, just to the right of a few small bushes, and to the right of the apparent "crack" system. Follow this up, then left over to the arrete, then traverse back over before the first big ledge (and tree). This is the crux; go over to the right before you've gone too high on the arrete. Top half is easy scrambling and occasional vertical moves going from ledge to ledge.
content.protection: 1 old bolt on top. Possible to tie of boulders and trees on top and set up anchors; easier to belay from top.
content.location: Rappel down is perhaps easier. From the Sentinel Rock summit, looking south, it is the face directly in front of you beyond that drops into the woods below.
